description.narrative: According to Serbia' environmental approximation strategy pollution abatement within industry is one of the three main challenges together with waste waster and solid waste management. The IPPC/IE directives regulates the area of industrial pollution and Serbia has transposed the IPPC directive and started implementation. The poultry and pork industry is the most far behind in terms of the directive and only a small minority has a valid IPPC permit. The planned contribution, with a support of 8.2 MSEK over two years, aims to increase the number of IPPC permits within this sub-sector, increase the number of application and improve the inspection activities. This project would be complimentary to an on-going IPA support within IPPC. Capacity building efforts will focus selected companies and municipalities but also involve the responsible Ministry in steering the project. The Cleaner Production CentreSerbia, CPCS, is a semi-autonous organization hosted by the Belgrade university and it has a long experience working with industrial pollution (and was established by UNIDO). CPCS is therefore considered very suitable to be the project implementor and has together with the Ministry presented a proposal which Sida finds both relevant and feasible. There are project risks in regards to authorities actually taking the decisons on new IPPC permits since this could, in the short-term, negatively affect the economy of companies and could therefore be politcally sensitive. Sida's overall assessment is still that the pressure for change is increasing and the chance for the project do deliver good results is fair. Sida needs to procure monitoring support for this contribution and the decision allocates funding for that purpose.

Enligt Serbiens strategi för närmande till EU på miljöområdet ("environmental approximation strategy") är industrins kommande miljöåtgärder en av de tre mest krävande områdena tillsammans med vatten och avlopp samt avfallshantering. EUs IPPC/IE-direktiv reglerar området och Serbien har endast kommit en liten bit på vägen och kyckling- och fläskproduktionen (djurstallar) är den delsektor som ligger sämst till avseende godkända IPPC-tillstånd. Insatsen, som är på två år och 8.35 MSEK, syftar till öka antalet inlämnade IPPC-ansökningar och beslutade tillstånd samt förbättra inspektionsverksamheten på området. Projektet kompletterar ett pågående IPA-stöd. De kapacitetsbyggande insatserna avser att fokusera företag och kommuner men även involvera ansvarigt ministerium i ledning och styrning av projeket. Cleaner Production Centre Serbia, CPCS, är en halvt fristående organisation på Belgrads universitet, vilken har lång erfarenhet av arbete med företagens miljöfrågor och har fått stöd i sin uppbyggnad av UNIDO (FNs organ för industrifrågor). CPCS anses väl lämpat att genomföra projeketet och har tillsammans med Ministeriet presenterat ett projektförslag som Sida bedömer relevant och genomförbart. Projektet innebär också risker vad gäller möjligheten för myndigheter att utverka tillstånd eftersom krav på företagens miljöprestanda kräver politiskt stöd. Helhetsbedömningen är ändå att trycket på förändring ökar successivt och att insatsen därför bör kunna ge goda resultat. Sida har också behov av att upphandla monitoringstöd för insatsen och avsätter därför medel i detta beslut.

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2017Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Out of the 226 industrial installations in Serbia where “EU Industrial Emissions Directive standards” applies, 93 are agriculture farms with intensive rearing of poultry and pigs. After two years, only some few Integrated Pollution Prevention Control (IPPC permits) had been issued, whereas 11 targeted representative operators are expected to receive IPPC permit within a year. Overall farm operators participation was high, as permits will increase their possibilities to receive export permissions to the EU market. Only 21 out of the 93 farm operators have not participated. The Project have addressed the entire IPPC permit process starting from drafting the application (support to farm operators), through writing the permits (support to the ministry and municipalities), to the enforcement and monitoring activities related to checks of compliance with permit conditions (support to the republic and local inspector). The new permit process has been formerly recognized in a new Rulebook for the intensive rearing sector adopted and published in the O.G. of Serbia number 32/2016 in April 2016. It will simplify procedures for farmers to apply IPPC permits. The former official rulebook dates back to 2006. New manuals, checklists and guidelines have been developed and operators and authorities including inspectors have had training. Best Available Techniques (BAT) are described and grouped in main topics in order to provide the operators with an easy accessible methodology to assess and evaluate the compliance with EU BAT (BREF) documents. The description takes into consideration Serbian context on Energy Efficiency, Waste Management, Monitoring, Emergency Management and Decommissioning and storage of manure and animal by-products management. It will facilitate for operators to assess investment requirements and time to obtain EU standards. This information will be used to formulate the Serbian EU negotiation position, in the intensive rearing sector, with regard to transition period.
